posts.com:
Welcome to the Nobody General

>Who is the Nobody?
The Nobody is a figure alive today who has extraordinary spiritual powers, including the ability to influence reality with his conscious and unconscious mind, and intuitively receive guidance from the forces of Heaven.
He works to elevate people to their true potential, opposing those who seek power over others. He's just like you, but he has found the kingdom of God within himself through sheer dedication, just like you will.

He isn't a savior; remember that it's you who creates your own reality. With your hands, thoughts, feelings, words, you are the creator of your story. No one can decide your fate except for you and God. Remember your right to power, to step up into your ultimate role as your highest self, should you choose to embark on that journey.

>What is the general picture?
It’s important we start replying more to the good posters and educating the hateful ones, so call upon their heads the forces of Heaven for peace, clarity, and wisdom. If this place is to be more than a squandered opportunity, an overgrown garden, it requires voices such as yours, but many more. This is a place for spiritual discussions and help, not drama, attention seeking, or social content; there are other boards for that.

Focus on increasing your service to all and be more loving to yourself and everyone in order to raise your vibrational and consciousness level, and learn to forgive yourself and others. This will change the vibration of the planet and raise our shared consciousness, making us a better humankind one person at a time.
None of us are perfect, it is by learning to admit and accept this fact one is able to learn, and grow in Truth. Heaven for all is real. Everyone's truest desires are mutual. The only motive is love.

If this is your first time here, just remember, it’s going to be ok, you may take shelter and find rest.

posts.name: Cookie Anon
posts.com:
Here is my cookie recipe for gnomes. Lot of anons in gen 140 asked me what i feed my housegnome.
Ingredients:
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks

Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

Schizophrenia or divided mind is a theory of psychosis instead of neurosis.

>>33608518
Already posted it in /gnomegen/ but here you go, this is the version i personally use
Ingredients:
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks

Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

You than have to leave it somewhere in your garden or in the woods. If you do it near mushroom circles it works almost 99% of the time.

>Do you really believe all of these things about yourself?
As I mentioned, I'm conflicted. I believe my fiancé is also right that I'm a nice person, and I know there are even people who look up to me. I don't think they're wrong to do so, as they look up to the good things about me. But that doesn't mean that what I wrote is false.

There are some nuances I didn't make clear:
>>I want others to feel that pain too.
That's not fully accurate. I want take pain from others, to the point that I get an urge to inflict it if I can justify it, just so that I can take it. If I can't justify it, then I repress that urge, but it's still there.

When I was little, I would beat up the people who tried to attack or bully me or others, until they started crying, and then I would help them up and apologise to them, bring them to the teacher to calm them down, and get them to apologise to the person they bullied (whether that was me or someone else). People complimented me for my strong sense of justice, but I felt guilty about it, as I knew I really did it because the pain and emotions involved fulfilled me, and not because I actually cared whether or not it was "right". Justice only served as an excuse to placate my conscience.
>>But why would they care about a monster like me?
This is just insecurity I feel due to my internal conflict, projected outwards.
>>My higher self does not know love. There is only spite, pain, sorrow, fear, and despair. I was born to spread it, and the resulting oneness is mistaken for love.
There is a resemblance here to how a parasite might amplify negative feelings and feed on them, that you wrote about on your blog - even to the point that actual feelings of love are confusing and frightening to my higher self. The fear in that case is that such overwhelming positive feelings might cause the negativity to dissipate.

>>33602011 >>33603206
Perhaps masochism is a better term here than sadism, although when vampirism is involved the latter is a form of the former. I first became aware of my higher self two years ago; most likely it was triggered by the reunion with someone I haunted in a past life (now my ex). In the culmination of the incident where I devoured everything I deemed negative within him (after which he broke down as he realised how delusional he'd been), it was as though leaving my vessel: my physical body lost consciousness, and I was an enormous chaotic black blob with hints of red, seeping into every crevice of his soul, swallowing his negative energy, upon which it was immediately made unrecognisable by the unrelenting cataclysm within me, simply becoming a part of it. I understood that this is my true form, and for some reason, it didn't really bother me, and I didn't stop to think about what it means until now.

Yesterday I confronted my higher self, or perhaps vice versa. I realised that the aforementioned blob is just the aura (almost completely opaque), and deep within it is what resembles a person. This person was frantic, and although he/she only screeched and snarled rather than speaking with words, I understood the cause of his/her dismay: "Lilith is trying to take the pain away. I don't know how to stop her." That person, that is to say "I", looked so utterly defeated over this, that I began to cry, knowing that even if I hugged myself, that would just be belittling.

How did it end up like this? An obsession with holding grudges from past lives. "I don't want to forget. I don't want to let go. If I moved on, would I still be me?" Getting used to one's own pain, then accumulating the pain of others too out of loneliness, until one feels like it's all one has and needs anymore.

As the lower self, having experienced countless joys thanks to Lilith turning my life around, I agree with Lilith more.

>>33602011 >>33603211
>How do you think your fiance would react if you said them to him?
I think he would cry, then somehow find a way to downplay it, and move on.

On a few occasions I've tried to intimidate him, as I felt like he underestimated my dark side and that made me feel lonely. Yet he insisted that I'm not monstrous, instead saying things like: "You're cute when you're edgy, too."

A few months ago, I told him that I don't think I'll ever understand his unwavering love for me, even though I feel the same way about him. I said I realised I lack the capability to register it. I explained that either I was born without it, or maybe I lacked something during crucial years of development. As such, I'm dependent on his attention and frequent reminders of his appreciation for my mental stability. Much of my behaviour is specifically tailored and intended to get him to appreciate me more. Without that, I'd forget that he loves me and have a panic attack.

He was very sad to hear it and cried. He asked a lot of questions, and I tried to soothe him without being dishonest. In the end, in his usual fashion, he spun it in a positive light: I'm just "needy" and appreciate his attention far more than most people would, and he'll gladly help me by making sure to provide it.

On the other hand, he recently opened up to me that he periodically has nightmares in which I reveal to him that dating him was actually a plot to grant him irreplaceable happiness, just so I can take it away and enjoy his suffering. At the time, I didn't understand where that idea came from, so I soothed him and reassured him I'd never do something like that, and then we made love, during which I focused on extracting the stress caused by the nightmare.

Given that I want to overcome this, I don't want to give him more reason to worry.

>>33602011 >>33603219
Even if I spend my whole lifetime living happily as a result of Lilith's intervention, I don't think it would change my mind about holding on to the pain - I'd just hold a grudge towards Lilith too, take the "loss", and try to gather more in the next life. But I'm not alone. As my connection with Lilith deepens, my higher self can't escape her either. She has already touched upon the darkness within me, and although letting go of it would never sit right with me, she might just be able to turn it into something nicer. And while on some level that frightens me, I know it's for the best. I'm still human enough to see that wallowing in misery to such an extent isn't right.

As for why she intervened, I assume my ancestor who works with her was (understandably) worried about me, and asked for help. When I prayed 8 years ago, I offered up my body and my soul if it meant my sorrow could be relieved; that in itself was a betrayal to my higher self, and one I intend see through to the end with Lilith's help. I shall achieve godhood and overpower myself with love and compassion, if that's what it takes for me to see the flaws in my ways. I won't reject the reasons behind the pain, but I'll relieve it anyway, and find positive ways to learn and move on.

Sorry for the wall of text; I wanted to type out all my thoughts in response to your questions, and was unsure what could be omitted.

>>33608205
I feel like telling this story after all; a glimpse into the sorrows of a distant past.

In my first life, my mother was a sex worker. After the first few years, my father took me away to raise me on his own in another town. He didn't want me to take after my mother, so as I grew up, he often referred to her with harsh words and warned me that I shouldn't become like her. I sometimes wanted to ask him: "What's so bad about wanting to make people feel good?", but I kept that to myself.

My father was summoned for war. I looked after his house by myself, awaiting his return. Eventually, I received word that he died in battle.

It was difficult to mourn his death while living alone, but the townspeople were kind to me. Eventually, as savings were running low, I began to wonder what I should do from here on out. I decided to ignore my father's warning and let my mother's line of work inspire me after all.

While socialising with the townspeople, I'd keep an eye out for men who seemed kind but troubled. I'd approach them in private and inform them of my services: conversation over a massage for a small fee, over at my house. If they actually visited and seemed like they were interested in more, I'd tell them I offer sexual services as well.

I enjoyed making people feel good while they let out their worries. I was rather sensitive to people's energy, which allowed me to intuitively develop tantric techniques to heal and soothe people spiritually at the same time. I refrained from engaging in coitus with my clients for a multitude of reasons, instead using other means to pleasure them.

One of my clients was a married man; I hadn't invited him personally, but apparently one of my other clients had recommended me to him. I wondered if I should reprimand him for coming to see me, but decided to at least hear him out first. He was a bit shy at first, but after some encouragement, began to complain about his wife. (1/2)

>>33608486
Upon hearing how awfully she treated him, I sympathised with him, and felt like he deserved better. I figured he would just find other ways to be disloyal even if I sent him away, so I told him he's welcome to come again, and he came to visit me frequently.

After hearing him out about his troubled marriage for several months, I'm not sure what got into me - perhaps I fell in love - but I asked him to forget about his wife, and devote himself fully to me instead. In return, I would likewise devote myself to him and give him everything he ever wished for in a partner; everything he deserves. He said he couldn't do that, but would like to keep seeing me. I didn't give up, and offered him to have sex with me rather than just the usual services, as well as to waive the fee. He took me up on my first offer, but insisted on paying me anyway.

From then on, I stopped enjoying my work. I felt jealous and resentful towards his wife, and was deeply lonely.

Eventually, rumours began to spread about what I did for a living. The women in town all hated me. Some of the men, even including some of my former clients, began to openly say very harsh things about me as well. I couldn't understand why. I didn't see what I did wrong. I'd always taken pride in my work: I soothed and helped people cope with the difficult times in their lives. What's so despicable about that? My remaining clients assured me that they appreciated me, but in the face of incessant public mockery and ostracisation, my self-esteem began to decline regardless.

The man I loved visited my home, as he often did, and I let him in. He told me that he fell out with his wife. I offered to make him feel better about it. He hit my face really hard, and I fell to the ground. Then he sat down on my legs, and began to punch my abdomen over and over. I could barely mutter, "why?" He growled and said repeatedly: "It's all your fault."

That's the last memory I have from that life, as I died.

Adding to the rest: it's about quality not quantity. Make it good, cut off a piece from the best part, put it on a tiny plate, then garnish if feeling especially loving. Place the offering near where you eat if possible or somewhere you frequent. You don't have to leave it out long, but at least while you are eating works.

You can find little cups and plates in Asian marts, fancy homegoods shops and often at second hand stores (check in among dishes or in case up front). They may be sold as espresso cups, tea sets, dipping dishes, candle holders or spoon/chopstick rests. If it looks like a plate or cup it works as one. Wash and purify before using ritually.

I'm going to add my few cents to the mix...

Some will tell you that true love is supposed to come easy. There's no forcing it to happen. And they, I believe, are right.

However... I think some also confuse "come easy" with convenience and "forcing it" with putting in the work/effort.

I found that true love doesn't give a shit about convenience. It doesn't remove the obstacles one must go through. It however does make it easier to confront the obstacles and put in the work.

Some things come more easily to others. So the prospect of true love landing in one's lap isn't unlikely. But in my experience it requires effort. And no matter how easily it comes, it's going to take effort and humility. As it takes two to tango, it also requires mutual effort. There's always the option to go with convenience. Or to ignore companionship/love altogether. For both parties.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And I'll add that I don't blame anyone that goes with the path of least resistance.

If someone were to move in the same apartment complex as I and we clicked enough (+ she showed interest), I can't say that wouldn't be tempting. Even knowing there's someone else that I know no one will compare to. A person that feels like home and my soul lights up for like no other.

With there being no direct desire or interest in the person I feel is a true love, it would be really hard not to go for that. Like desiring a nourishing meal but one would have to put in effort to get it. Where as one could also just pick up a cheap hot and ready pizza. The latter will fill ya up and keep you sated. But ultimately it'll leave you feeling empty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One more post, I have a lot to say on this particular subject but I didn't want to do one long post...

Also, just some bits of unsolicited advice from my own perspective...

- If finding true love is something that is important to you. Then it should surely be a goal to pursue. I agree with those that said don't go looking for it. Be open to it and it will find you. And it shouldn't be one's only goal in life. Even if, there's a lot of inner work and self-love that needs to be focused on in order to allow that true love to flourish and grow.

- True love doesn't mean it's going to be any less painful. It's going to cause you to face your inner shadows and trauma conditioning. And that doesn't feel pleasant. It's going to make you aware of faults/triggers/bad habits that you wouldn't likely normally run into if not seeking an honest connection. And as far as I can tell, there's no end to it. It likely gets easier with both parties working through it together. But that also brings with it the awkward and uncomfortable feelings of being vulnerable, direct, and non-confrontational.

- Don't be afraid to show love. Not just with someone you consider your true love but with people you love in general. The world can be a cold lonely place and those feelings you might think are too much or will be received poorly aren't doing any good kept to oneself.

>>33590322

This one is actually surpisingly coherent.
The King is Solomon, son of David,a major figure in all Abrahamic religions, revered for his wisdom, despite being essentially a pagan mage-king, who regularly consorted with various spirits, both good and evil. This is mainstream stuff from both testaments.
Aside from that, there are some ancient Jewish texts in which it is said that Solomon had a magical ring (the Seal of Solomon) which is engraved with the symbol known today as the Star of David. In fact this is the entire reason Jews use said symbol - because of the protective powers attributed to the Seal (and even its depictions) by later (mostly late medieval) sources.
In those stories, Solomon received the ring as a gift directly from God, to aid him in his quest for wisdom and knowledge. The ring would allow him to communicate with and command both angels and demons.
He later uses the ring to make demons follow a certain set of rules when interacting with mortals, two of which are mentioned in the meme picture.
1)Demons cannot reveal themselves to mortals.
2)Demons cannot directly speak to mortals.
The author of the meme therefore alleges that the internet (and by that logic every other form of distant communications) was invented by demons to circumvent the aforementioned rules.

1) Pic related, LoA teachers in general don't recommend an SP--in the sense of a person you know--for different reasons, mainly for it being pointless/limiting. They DO recommend just going for love in general and trust the subconscious to lead you to an ideal mate
2) It's limiting because you think you know what you want best, but the point of LoA is to understand that your conscious mind/ego doesn't really know all that, the subconscious knows much more and has a broader perspective on your happiness
3) We've seen this play out practically in these threads plenty of times, where the vast majority of people that report on an SP actually get relationship, but by the time they get the relationship they don't care about that person anymore. So chances are, you're actually wasting your time if you go for someone you know, and should just skip that step and go for love in general

People used to make their own food, there was a big resistance to the current system of depending on it because the option is starving, but the current system is making the poorer poorer and the richer richer, and it couldn't have been put in place without enforcing monogamy and marriage, the sooner people realize that the sooner we'll have a more free society.

>>33610101
To be honest if your friend broke the other's nose I don't know if they were such great friends. I used to be part of a group of "friends" that talked at eachother's backs all the time and had constant infighting. Since I essentially left that group my mental wellbeing has drastically improved. This is, funnily, around the time I learned about the one who would become my SP.
That said, EYPO. I won't say you divided them but they did in your inner world, so they could just as well be reunited.

But I think this is just like one of those "Manifest my ex back" stories. Can you do it? Absolutely, I managed to do so. My ex went from saying they weren't attracted to me and blocking me, to contacting me out of the blue, apologizing, complimenting my looks and inviting me over. But in the meanwhile I've become a completely different person and started to manifest the new SP. So I just politely friendzoned my ex. The manifestation gurus would say I "revised" them. Did I? Well, I simply lived in the assumption the ex was in a bad place in their life and were lying to themselves- when they apologized they essentially did repeat the first half of that.

So it's the same with your friends, any relationship can of course be an SP. You can manifest them back, but if you haven't worked on yourself and your assumptions you'll also manifest back their past infighting and grudges.
Or you can manifest new friends without all the baggage. A lot of people here will say not to manifest a *specific* SP (SSP?) period, but I agree with NevilleGoddess who in a video neatly differentiates between old SSPs (ex BFs/GFs, ex friends, etc) and whole new SSPs. She recommends against the former (she tried to do so herself, only to stop wanting her ex-BF back) but says nothing against the latter. But you are God and ultimately you decide what's best for you. Paraphrasing NGoddess once more, don't seek guidance from others because you already have all answers within you. Godspeed.

From 78 Degrees of Wisdom:

>In readings the Emperor indicates (following the Rider pack image) the power of society, its laws and especially its authority to enforce those laws. The appearance of the trump indicates an encounter with the law. Again, the good or bad qualities depend on the context. More personally the Emperor can signify a time of stability and order in a person's life, hopefully opening up creative energy. He also can indicate a specific person who holds great power, either objective or emotional, over the subject. This is very often the father, but it can also be a husband or lover, especially for those people who treat their lovers as substitute fathers to whom they surrender control of their lives. I have seen readings so dominated by the Emperor that all of life's possibilities become stunted and unfulfilled. As a card of personal qualities, the Emperor can indicate the ability to defend one's territory, to create firm boundaries and vigorously maintain them. He symbolizes a rationalist approach to issues, one that values analysis and measurement over emotion and intuition.

-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

last step is waiting for hypnagogia with multiple senses and interact with it
i suggest doing this after wbtb or at least in the process of taking a nap, doing it at the beginning of the night is practically like waiting an hour at the bus stop
hope this helps, gl dayo

Had an insane lucid dream. Like most of them sex was in it but scattered between everything for some reason. I was actually able to consciously speak to my own mind. I'm assuming that's what dreams are made of, since a single thought and the entire landscape changes.

Skipping the boring bits and bubbling them down: like most nightmares I came across some bad shit that chased me, but I chased them back since I was lucid and they ran scared lol. Anyways, I was walking down this school highway with all these kids and we were going to recess. I caught up with one random kid and tried talking to him. Eventually he turned into a kid version of me, and I tried explaining to him how surreal this was literally talking to myself. He didn't say much, but his smile was bright and he kept nodding. It felt like he knew all along what I was going to say. I wanted to tell him how much he mattered to me, how I'd promise to take good care of him and if he needed anything, just tell me. He seemed to understand. Kind of wish he spoke more, but it was still cool having some kind of dialogue with myself. Which sounds retarded in retrospect but anyone who has done lucid dreams I'm sure will tell you: it's a lot cooler talking to yourself and being able to hold your own hand, then it is when you're awake.

posts.com:
Lately my attitude towards everything has been vastly improved, by choice. I'm saying positive affirmations a lot, am doing yoga, eating well, and generally have a more empowered feeling. This has been reflected in my dreams! I have more awareness in general, and more control once I become lucid.
The other night set the bar higher for me. I woke up about half an hour before my alarm, and decided to have a good dream for the remaining time. I lay in bed thinking about all the people I'm thankful to have in my life, and then proceeded to dream for what felt like an entire day, about going to a "waterpark" with my fiancée. It was sort of like the poolrooms, only outside, in the sun. Occasionally, I would get the typical worries I get while on vacation - is the dog being taken care of well, etc. But then I would remind myself it was just a dream. Literally the best dream I've ever had.
I've changed my tactic basically. Rather than becoming lucid and trying to teleport to where I want to be, I set positive intentions while awake and then go lucid in whatever place I end up. Guides in this general have helped a lot!
Last night I was exploring with some old classmates and current coworkers. One said something about the "other kids" getting candy. So I decided to find it, and voila, found the stairs leading up to the "candy room". I ate sour patch kids and M&Ms. The colors were so vivid and the sugar rush felt real. I think I'm in a childlike place mentally/spiritually.

Had a very short lucid dream last night. I'm a pretty regular lucid dreamer but it's still great to get them.
>reading sheet music in my loungeroom in preparation for a rehearsal
>the piece is real, "Ride" by Sam Hazo ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=au4geHy_S_0 ), but it doesn't look like how it should
>everything's properly legible but it doesn't fit with the piece as I know it
>look up
>a woman I don't really recognise is sitting at the table
>look at the far wall
>there's a bird cage on a pedestal and one of my pet cockatiels sitting on top of the cage
>waitaminute, my last cockatiel died years ago and I got rid of that cage when I decided no more birds
>I'M DREAMING
>there's a decent amount of resistance in the dream to me becoming lucid
>at first there's a small amount of doubt because of how real and normal everything feels, then things shift a little bit and I know that I was correct
>the light coming in the windows disappears like it suddenly became late evening outside
>the woman disappears
>get up and leave the house through the front door
>yep, it's pretty dark, feeling a bit uneasy
>a small insect buzzes my ear, looked like a fly
>grab it and it stays still
>90% sure something bad's going to happen despite my lucidity, which usually means something bad will happen
>reach the street and look down it
>there's a cluster of beautiful blue lights in the road a little bit further down the street
>as I get closer they start to form an emblem, which I was absolutely gobsmacked by its beauty
>took a good look at it so I could attempt to replicate it, but my skills aren't good enough in waking life to do it anywhere near the justice it deserves
>attempt to take a steam screenshot of it, even hear the click and even see the screenshot taken panel in my vision
>think to myself "There's no way that's going to persist after I wake up. A screenshot from a dream would be worldshattering"
>leave the dream an unusual way, feels like I'm being pulled upwards to my bed

for the ultra clear one? I became lucid in the dream, it was accidental
but I remember that I was sleeping disastrously all the previous days, only naps like that day(literally) and at that moment I think I had an alarm activated because I wanted to get up later to eat something... so i guess it was a bit of WBTB too

now i only have lucid dreams when i am a bit sleepy (not too much) i lie on my back and do breathing exercises focusing on it while i am listening to something on youtube at a very low volume
once I think I didn't even do breathing exercises and I only paid attention (a bit) to the audios I put on but I refused to sleep
other times I didn't pay attention to the audio (but still audio playing) but I did pay attention to what I saw in the dark
and other times the same but while I tried to move my "ghost" body (breathing exercises, you feel sleepy but then you start trying to move your body without moving a single muscle, as if you were preparing to move but you don't)... I think this was the most useful for me, now that I remember. I think I'm going to try again right now, I haven't done it in a long time.
the trick is to remain conscious but RELAXED to tell your brain or body that you are already sleeping while your consciousness is still active
Whatever you choose to do, it's extremely important that you do not move a single physical muscle or open your eyes, that's what all my successful attempts agree on

I'm going to deboonk Rh- autism.

Rh- is nothing more than a marker for potential. Potential to be homozygous for other genes that grant natural psychic abilities.
That's it.
Every single phenotypical expression that Rh-s have, Rh+s do as well. Central heterochromia, red hair, green eyes, left handedness, intuition, empathy, psychic abilities, skull shape, extra vertebra and ribs, etc. are all present in RH+ people as well.

So the only reason for harping on and on about RH- blood is because it MAY be a marker that indicates someone MAY have these attributes.
The number of genes that give someone all of these attributes and the like is probably in the dozens. And we don't know what kind of genes they are so we don't know how they're inherited. So an RH- person could have none of the traits, and an Rh+ could have all of them and vice versa. Therefore, the Rhesus antigen has no meaningful /x/ relevance.
So to

It's hard to explain, imagine feeling separate from your body, recognizing this separation, and then just 'taking a step out' to a sort of 'middle ground' zone. I can do this to such a rate of efficiency that during some more mundane events with very little mental focus I can step out to the point that I actually lose track of time. It makes long drives so, so, so, so much more tolerable.

While I step out like this, I engage in all sorts of activities. From speaking to others who are not there, to trying to recall events not of this life, to simply asking the various forces around me why things feel so jarring and wrong. Things respond to me like this, I also don't feel so alone.

I've explained some of the dreams I've had to friends and coworkers and I have legitimately gotten responses that they feel I go places after describing the events.

posts.com:
I feel like we need to make some sort of general plan on what to do after death. We actually sort of know what happens after death because of near death experiences and children being able to remember past incarnations.

What happens is first you are just floating there in your astral/energy body for a variable amount of time. After that you get sucked through a tunnel and go into "heaven". You will have some light beings there that act as guides. They will take you to a bright wall of light, some sort of test. No ones really sure about what that is. Next the light beings will replay your entire life for you. You will feel how your actions effected others. If you made fun of someone, you will feel their hurt. The beings will then try to convince you to reincarnate. They will present you with Jesus or your dead relatives or anything that will convince you to go back to try again, do better next life. If you accept, they will help you plan your next incarnation. You bullied a kid? Well now he'll be your best friend!!! It seems like the one thing these beings can't do is force you to incarnate. If you refuse they put you in a void.

Thats suuuper manipulative. Tricking someone with godly power into thinking that they are so unworthy that they need to go into a whole 'nother life to try again.

Fuck that. I'm not reincarnating. I'm not staying in the void. I'm not listening to these devils posing as angels. I am finding another option. And in order to find that option I think we need to band together. We need to make some sort of plan to come against these beings that keep tricking us into coming here. Sure, there are some good parts of life but thats like saying that you still have some "good times" in an abusive marriage. You're still being manipulated, beaten and abused into staying.

What we need is some way to contact each other, probably in the void. Some sort of clarion call we can all rally around.

Occasionally the visuals would peel back like a curtain, revealing some sort demonic, smiling, taunting, laughing, predatory, black and white, jester-like faces that felt simultaneously like they were approaching me while I was being pulled toward them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33606730
Oh but it wasn't all negative. I also had one of the most strange, positive, and profound experiences during that trip and I have no way to fully describe it. Towards the end of the peak I had this intuitive urge to meditate by "being still" and focusing my attention solely on "stillness". I did so while zoning out on my palm, and the world instantly disappeared. The trip turned off. I suddenly felt sober, like I no longer had a body and no longer existed in physical space.

All I could perceive was a pale golden light and a steady drone, and I felt very peaceful and full of joy. It felt like I was outside of time and space but I still had a very fuzzy sense of time, as it only felt like I was "there" for about 30 seconds, but I felt like "there" was "here", "everywhere", and "nowhere, simultaneously. I felt like I somehow was the light and the sound that I perceived. I had the sense that if I had stayed in that state that I'd have been able to safely visit any time or place from that state, but I was too excited to stay still and try. After I snapped back, I instantly was tripping again, but weaker, the bad trip vibes were gone, and I felt fine. Just extremely confused about what just happened and a bit excited. Ever since then my focus shifted from psychedelics to meditation. I'd like to trip again with a plan to specifically meditate next time and see if I can reproduce it, after getting a bit better at and more familiar with meditation. The most I can do now is get my monkey brain to fuck off for a couple minutes max, but before that experience I had absolutely no experience with meditation, so maybe that's more than enough with the aid of psychedelics next time. Never touching purple mystics again though.

Blog posting again because I've never been able to wrap my head around what exactly happened and I guess I'm hoping some random lurker might shed some light on it if I'm lucky.

With that being said I think he is genuine in his motives and his work, even if he can be a kind of goofy fox news boomer conservative. I don’t believe this was his strongest movie, and I think he would have to 2x the length and budget to really get the point across. I felt if he focused on purely wyoming cases and left out the Elk abduction, the BC case, and the Arizona case he could have made a stronger point. I know he was trying to drive home the German abductee case, but he could have just listed raw data of German missing people.

I think the films structure was off, he needed to set the ground work with missing persons cases, then explain to the viewer the interdimensional hypothesis (vallee), and then execute on the pattern of the cluster map, elk, germans, etc. I was disappointed he didn’t show the cluster map with the aquifer in one scene.

With all that being said, he had some beautiful shots on location, and considering he funds most of this himself it’s better than 95% of paranormal so documentaries. This is a film for the initiated, not the skeptics or the entryists, i recommend sharing The Hunter with anyone wanting to get into 411 type stuff.

I'm not a doctor and i'm not trained in biology, so my opinion on this doesn't come from any expertise, but as an independent thinker I've critically analysed the claims for and against viruses, especially and specifically covid, and I've come to the position that viruses simply don't exist, or that there certainly isn't good strong evidence to believe in them in most cases. This is obviously a position that sounds insane at first, as it sounded to me only two years ago, but that's the position I've come to, and I think anyone who actually looks into this and is capable of questioning things can see the same.

You claim you had multiple shifting symptoms for example. Well the official position on covid is that it can seemingly cause practically any condition - but most generally it was thought to be defined by flu-like symptoms, literally all the symptoms point by point that you get with flu. In Wuhan the original panic started because they claimed there was "atypical pneumonia", pneumonia being often a flu symptom or associated with flu... but since the original outbreak, the wider epidemiology shifted the definition so that there isn't really anything 'atypical' about the pneumonia of those who experience covid.

You didn't catch a virus because viruses don't exist and aren't contagious. Now what actually causes your illness I don't know. In my own case I had a 'flu' in Feb of 2020, and then the next illness I had was a short flu in 2022, with my new perspective I came to the conclusion that the probably triggering factor was a sudden drop in temperature (literally the entire state ran out of tissues over this week) during an antarctic blast (Australia), and the fact that i'd experienced sleeping under a 'drafty' window. This is just speculation though, I don't definitively know what actually causes 'flu' now that I don't believe in viruses.

anyway, when you find a silex (many commoners, they're fine), best way to get it going is to use your body heat. i poofmaxxed a smooth quartzite or maybe white agate, idek rn, in 2h. a large one. but those are the definitive mid-tier average-price silexes. coarser, "dumber" ones are faster to do everything, fine ones take more time. wash the silex with hot water, let it get used to its new home (they can be shy at first when you bring them in. or not. depends on specie and individual, some are outgoing, others are not), heat it up with your hands.
when it changes appearance, namely by poofing, and changes temperatures (it gets very cold most of the time at first, then avg temp when up and running smooth). making nanoclimates, changing temperature (if hot, probably leave it be. or it can get hot while at work), they're cool when active usually. they're kinda opposite to us organisms. they can emit psychic messages, they're astral computers. you really gotta try it! clay fields are where they can best be found. sometimes they make their ways to paved areas, though.
they also work in spurts. bigger ones have more power, pebbles just need to grow. you can watch them do this over weeks. however, they seem to compete for resources, that woowoo aether chow. resources are thin over here. when i gave some away, at home i could FEEL fewer hungry "mouths" in the area. the more silexes i got, the slower they grew. some are just on pause, presumably until their competition leaves. i intend to get the most attractive non-keep specimens out there, to make a good impression. the rough ones can then grow faster.
so yeah, they work in short spurts with electromagnetic beams. try it.

I saw Nexpo at a grocery store in Los Angeles yesterday. I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didn’t want to be a douche and bother him and ask him for photos or anything. He said, “Oh, like you’re doing now?” I was taken aback, and all I could say was “Huh?” but he kept cutting me off and going “huh? huh? huh?” and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued with my shopping, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to pay for my stuff up front I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen Milky Ways in his hands without paying.

The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like “Sir, you need to pay for those first.” At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter.

When she took one of the bars and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually “to prevent any electrical infetterence,” and then turned around and winked at me. I don’t even think that’s a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.

>>33595807
Your body is physically lifting (itself) up or you have the sensation of floating upwards? For some, leaving the body can feel the way you're describing. Other people "roll out" or "twist out" or "leak out" from their body, and some even just appear outside. There are lots of somatic sensations taking place when you practice mind-awake-body-asleep states of consciousness.

>>33595834
If you want to progress further in this, you will have to work on your fear response. Fear is such a disruption to the process of going OOB. Visual sensations such as the one you're posting are also present in feinting episodes. The vibrations are also part of many people's response.

So, take heart: you have good potential to regularly go OOB, but you're going to want to work out your fear response. OOB is probably the most harmless thing you can do as a mind, precisely because what you know of harm is explicitly linked to the physical material of the body. So... nothing is going to hurt you, you're not going to get stuck in a strange place, and you are likely to experience something that fundamentally encourages your growth beyond limits you've unwittingly created for yourself.

>Ape's Library

>Mysticism
Jewish — Jewish Meditation
Hindu — Raja Yoga
Taoist — Foundations of Internal Alchemy
Theravada — Knowing and Seeing
Zen — Zen Mind Beginner's Mind
Sufi — Sufism for Non-Sufis
Christian — Cloud of Unknowing

>Grimoires
Agrippa's Three Books are a must
Arbatel should be the first grimoire to work with; later on you can work with Heptameron, Goetia, Book of Abramelin, Picatrix, etc.
The PGM tend to be pretty modular

>Vajrayana
Intro to Tantra, Refining Gold. Garchen Rinpoche and HHDL's entire YouTube catalogs; you can even take empowerment and transmission from their recordings, if vows are understood. Look into centers in your area & others that offer empowerment online. Avoid NKT, Rigpa, and Shambhala. You can also self-initiate with the Samadhi Empowerment
studybuddhism.com

>Golden Dawn
In order: Tree of Life, Mystical Qaballah, Middle Pillar, Golden Dawn

>Aurum Solis
Magical Philosophy (70s editions go from I-V, modern ones from I-III), then Planetary Magick
Their Practical Guide series for whatever

>Martinism
In the Freemason folder there is Martinism folder — read everything
Then try to find Treatise on the Reintegration of Beings, as well as the works of Saint-Martin and Papus, in French
youtube.com/c/OrdreMartinistesSouverains

>Aspire to A∴A∴
Have a basic understanding of the Golden Dawn system. Read Liber ABA, then go through this reading list:
ordoaa.org/studlist.htm
Focus on Liber Resh, E , RV, O, Astarte, and HHH
For a full curriculum, Mystical and Magical System of the A∴A∴

>Chaos Magic
Liber Null and Psychonaut, Condensed Chaos, Liber Kaos, Hands-On Chaos Magic, Six Ways

>Theosophy/Sophiology
Pseudo-Dionysius: The Complete Works
Angelic Spirituality
Theologia Mystica (janelead.org/resources.html)
Way to Christ first, then the rest of Jakob Böhme
jacobboehmeonline.com
Initiation into Three Worlds
An Outline of Sophiology

>>33598203
Yes.
In terms of cultivating energy, half lotus is about 3x faster than zero lotus, and full lotus is about 3x faster than half lotus.
Over time your nervous system gets rewired to handle those energies, and your joints and flexibility get rebuild to handle the stresses.

Zero lotus allows the energy to fall into the root chakra.
Half lotus tends to raise the energy to the heart or middle dantien.
Full lotus tends to raise the energy to the brain or upper dantien.

If you're not doing energy cultivation then there is no need for full lotus.
Sitting in full lotus too much can cause kundalini psychosis, but this isn't usually a problem for beginners who don't have a lot of energy built up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33601210
Probably they would be generally helpful, as long as you keep your eye on the idea of "balanced energy".

I used to do a series of asanas and pranayama exercises before sitting in full lotus, and found that it definately deepened my practice sessions.
I found the following pretty helpful:
A taichi exercise that circulates the microsmic orbit. I would alternate this exercise with horse stance for about 2 minutes while doing one round of quickfire breathing, and hop into horsestance on the exhale.
Very powerful, and there was a definate feeling after 20-40 minutes of my brain flooding with chi or serotonin or spinal fluid - whatever you want to call it, because I don't really know what it was.
Then once I had that flushed feeling in my brain, I knew that sitting in full lotus would give much deeper pleasure.
Then I would do headstand asana to flush my brain even more, and then alternate nostril breathing alternating with Whim Hof breathing (quickfire breathing).
This would cause a trance state.
Then I would sit in full lotus with a silent mind, and deep pleasure would come on pretty fast.
Sometimes I would do some kriya spinal breathing exercises, but it's not really needed as the energy circulates on its own.
Whim Hof breathing was a good exercise to do while sitting in lotus, to get the chi circulating again if it was still for too long, and there is a feeling of "cavitation pressure" where the lower dantien compresses very rapidly, and this generates heat in the dantien.

But over time, the nerves and such gets rewired, so just sitting in full lotus without all those extra exercises becomes much more powerfully than when the practice first started, so I don't really need it anymore as it powerful enough.

But yeah to keep it really simple, you just need to sit in full lotus, with the tongue to the roof your mouth, with a silent mind, and some degree of celibacy.

>>33600585
>music related deities that pop up there
I live in the southern USA and have moved around the area for most of my life. Most people out here are Christian due to this being deep in the Bible Belt. Christians have a lot of musical tradition out here, mostly stemming from church music. You know, hymns and such. The whites spun off bluegrass, country, folk. The blacks spun off spirituals and work chants, which became Hip Hop or Rap.

As to non-Abrahamic faiths? The most common ones are Gardnerian Wicca, Buddhism and various cobbled together versions of Native spirituality. These all draw influence musically from whatever countries the artist has in their background. There are no specific "Gods of music" in any of these that I am aware of.

>TL;DR:
Music out here comes from practice and trying new variations on old themes. There is no supernatural secret or shortcut.

posts.name: Woodie

>>33604037
Well a lot of it has to do with the cultural "polite indifference" and capitalism diluting the occult, especially with passive new age ideas, post-80s Satanic Panic.

While I practice witchcraft and started so in the 2000s, I myself was rural enough in a heavily protestant culture that my forays had a danger to them. Here I was skipping school, the son of a Pastor, and going to the only occult bookstore a town away to get my dark curiosities satisfied. A store that during that time was firebombed, burnt down, and the standard satanic-panic accusations levied against. Learning to take covers off of books and replacing them with something innocuous to avoid detection. Rumors in a local witch group of infiltration by the police department.

There was something to the occult in those days that came with danger and fear. Navel gazing and positive visualizations aside, there was some dark stuff out there and I craved it. I stil recall the first book that actually offered a witchcraft resembling the imagery of my fathers sermons on witchcraft, Mastering Witchcraft by Paul Huson, being the bingo moment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33605030
Full lotus causes the microcosmic orbit to spin.
That's why it's such an important exercise in taoist energy cultivation.
Half lotus does the same, but it's less effective.
When sitting in lotus, the energy will do two major things - either it will circulate in the microcosmic orbit, or it will gather one of the dantiens - typically the lower dantien when you are first starting out. If you don't have enough chi built-up, then you won't really feel anything, but doing some Whim Hof breathing can jumpstart the microcosmic orbit, and also cause "cavitation" of the lower dantien, where it rapidly compresses and generates heat.

The purpose of an empty mind is that chi goes where the attention goes. So if you allow your mind to wander, then the chi will disperse among many different nerve pathways, and cultivation will be much slower. But if you can be completely silent, or concentrated, even for a few seconds, then the energy cultivation will be much more powerful, as the chi will gather in the microcosmic orbit and begin to circulate.

As an example, I find that chanting mantras ussually stops the microcosmic orbit from flowing, but if I just sit silently, then it circulates very well on it's own. Some traditions recommend visualizing a white light as the chi circulates, while others recommend that just being silent is the best, as the chi has an intelligence of its own.

>>33606106
First you must realize that what you're trying to achieve is a non-action. There is no "doing". Trying to stop grasping is essentially suppression. You must sharpen your mind to contemplatively realize how it moves to the objects that you grasp to, and combine that with the wisdom of emptiness and non-identification. This is an integrative process that happens by itself as you sharpen your awareness and surrender to your phenomenological experience. Once you become adept at realizing (witnessing without indulgence or aversion ) how your entire sensorial apparatus clings and grasps, and how that brings you suffering, you organically start noticing these unskillful patterns and gradually stop submitting to them. But the change is in your view, in your perception of yourself and of your relationship of yourself and your sensory experience.

tl;dr: meditate your ass off my nigga

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are three core aspects to our lives.

The body, the mind and the spirit.

These three aspects are connected to some extent, which I will touch upon as I go through.

The body is your general existence as a man. The material world.

Pain, pleasure, movement, touch... Self explanatory.

Next is the mind.

The mind is whenever you think with your head. Think, of all the concerns of life that distract us you.

What are you wondering right now?

The mind is also connected with the body. When the body is hungry, it becomes a thought, then you act on the thought.

Last and not least is...

The spirit.

This is what is truly us. Beyond the body and beyond the mind. Our soul, if you will.

This is a feeling, an essence, deep within and what I think people operate with as they are young.

However, as they age, elements of life (trauma, material reward, worry, deceit) tend to put parts of the mind (ego, self-consciousness) in control, displacing the spirit (unless it is recovered).

The spirit is connected with the mind when we dream in the day or in the night.

The extent of this connection is difficult for me to elaborate on so I'll leave it at that. Maybe someone here can explain it better.

Now, feelings of the spirit are unseen as they are not of this world.

These feelings, should they come to you, overshadow typical life.

That is to say, life lived through the mind and body does not compare to life lived through the spirit.

If you've ever listened to a special melody, or have an affinity for nature, or wholeheartedly read the Word of God, you will know of this feeling like I have.

It is fulfilling and great. The greatest gift one can receive.

Indeed, men do have souls.

For this, which I have not felt for most of my life, and this wisdom, I have the most high God, our Heavenly Father, Whom have us Jesus Christ, to thank and give glory to.

Thanks for reading and I hope this reaches you well. God bless you all.

>>33571071
Throughout Christ’s ministry, He frequently used these three terms: “Hades,” “Gehenna,” and the “Lake of Fire.” Each has a different meaning; however, they are often treated interchangeably and get mistranslated as “hell.”
Hades is the Greek term for the Underworld, the abode of the dead. Hades is “Sheol” in Hebrew. Adamites have an eternal spirit so when they die, their bodies decay but their spirits abide in Hades/Sheol awaiting Christ’s second coming. Peter explained that Hades is where Christ visited the “spirits in prison” during the three days between His death and resurrection when He preached the gospel “also to them that are dead.”
Here we see that an Adamite can turn to Christ after death, which is entirely opposite to the teachings of most modern churches. Christ states in Revelation that He will “destroy Hades and Death,” and all Adamite spirits will be released and return to Him in heaven. There will no longer be death for Adamites. It’s as simple and cut and dry as that.
There is no “hell.”

So where do the other two terms fit into this? Gehenna is a compound Hebrew word. It refers to the “valley of Hinnom,” the wicked place where in Jeremiah’s time the Israelites sacrificed their children as burnt offerings to Baal.
When Christ used the word Gehenna, He was referring allegorically to the fiery trials in this life. This includes the chastisement Yahweh visits on the Israelites when they stray. As in the literal Gehenna, one’s body may be allegorically burned during these fiery trials.
One’s body may be punished or even destroyed in this life. However, the eternal Adamic soul will be saved. Therefore it is important to distinguish between the words Hades and Gehenna in order to understand what Christ is saying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33571066
>>33571071
The third term — the “lake of fire” — refers to the complete destruction awaiting all non-Adamic peoples. As Christ explained in the parable of dividing the nations, the sheep and goat nations will be finally and definitively be separated from each other.
The two nations are the Israelites and the non-Adamics. Their fate is then outlined: “These [goat nations] will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous [sheep nations] into eternal life.” Here “eternal punishment” should be translated as “lake of fire.” This means they cease to exist completely and forever.

Churches teach that you could spend eternity in hell if you don’t obey your priest and attend church. These teachings do not follow scripture because scripture clearly states that your origin determines your destiny.
Christ has saved His Adamic creation, so Adamites will be restored and judged for the life they led. Since Adamites have eternal life, Yahweh has good reason for punishing and chastising them in this life. He is correcting them and making them better.
But since all non-Adamites will be tossed into the lake of fire and destroyed utterly, they are never corrected and punished for their actions in this life.
Mistranslating “hell” misleads and obscures this truth. It clouds our understanding and leads us to believe that some Adamites might not make it to heaven. This leaves the door open for accepting non-Adamics as Christians and even brethren.

Isaiah 10

Against a godless nation I send him,
and against the people of my wrath I command him,
to take spoil and seize plunder,
and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.
But he does not so intend,
and his heart does not so think;
but it is in his heart to destroy,

Howbeit he meaneth not so - It is not his purpose to be the instrument, in the hand of God, of executing his designs. He has a different plan; a plan of his own which he intends to accomplish.
Neither doth his heart think so - He does not intend or design it. The "heart" here, is put to express "purpose, or will."

It is "in his heart to cut off nations - Utterly to destroy or to annihilate their political existence.

Not a few - The ambitious purpose of Sennacherib was not confined to Judea. His plan was also to invade and to conquer Egypt; and the destruction of Judea, was only a part of his scheme; Isaiah 20:1-6 (http://biblehub.com/isaiah/20-1.htm). This is a most remarkable instance of the supremacy which God asserts over the purposes of wicked people. Sennacherib formed his own plan without compulsion.

He devised large purposes of Ambition, and intended to devastate kingdoms. And yet God says that he was under his direction, and that his plans would be overruled to further his own purposes. Thus 'the wrath of man would be made to praise him;' Psalm 76:10 (https://biblehub.com/psalms/76-10.htm). And from this we may learn

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33603686

(1) That wicked people form their plans and devices with perfect freedom. They lay their schemes as if there were no superintending providence; and feel, correctly, that they are not under the laws of compulsion, or of fate.

(2) That God presides over their schemes. and suffers them to be formed and executed with reference to his own purposes.

The reason astrology is so useful is because it makes you think about stuff you otherwise wouldn't. >>33588971
The laws of physics are just math equations, and a lot of them have seemingly arbitrary constants. It is possible to imagine universes in which the equations are slightly different - where a constant is 6.6744 x 10^11 instead of 6.6743 x 10^11, for example. Yet, when one starts examining the repercussions of these changes, one finds again and again that virtually any other set of constants and equations produces worlds that are simply unable to host intelligent life. Everything collapses into a black hole, or stars never shine, or everything collapses into radioactive dust. As the universe seems to be something of a one-off - and our modern understanding of physics tells us that any of these other combinations *might* have come to pass after the big bang - a lot of people conclude that the sheer unlikelihood of our existence is proof that the universe was designed this way.
Personally, I think it suggests that our incomplete understanding of physics will eventually reveal that many of these seemingly independent variables were actually connected all along (in the way that the length of two sides of a right triangle dictate the length of the third side) and that as such the odds of this particular universe were much higher than they currently seem because many of the inhospitable possibilities were never valid in the first place. But that's just my opinion.

My opinion: Western atheism in particular is intellectually weak due to the fact that it usually constitutes a rejection of specific articulations of the numinous (most often abrahamistic ideations of 'god', and occasionally expanded to other mythic, historical pantheons) and this rejection is often based on literalistic rather than symbolic readings of source materials. And while many atheists will say that they outright reject any and all notions of deity, they would be hard pressed to articulate every potential variation of what might constitute 'deity' — or even offer a survey of every historic articulation of what constitutes deity.

So insomuch as an 'atheist' can articulate which specific ideations of deity they reject, and why, then I certainly can respect their position on their specific terms if it is well-reasoned; but as a blanket default position, atheism strikes me as the reactionary, somewhat dim-witted younger sibling of agnosticism.

But that's just my take. Cheers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: The Cult of Creativity and The Creative Singularity
posts.com:
Once upon a time a group of artists, musicians, poets, writers, scientists, philosophers, historians, theologians, engineers, and many others came together from a shared love of learning. They cross-pollinated each other's ideas and experiences with novel insights, helping each other to explore connections between fields they didn't consider before. The more they shared, the more interconnected they found themselves to be. They began to look at what they were doing, and found that their root commonality was creativity. And so they began to worship creativity itself, considering creativity as the most important thing in the world.

The Cult of Creativity spread the message of creativity by organizing public lectures and talks, workshops, star parties, funded libraries, and inspirational messages about the power of creativity. The cult grew and grew, and was welcomed by many as a learning movement.

The cult also investigated the nature of creativity itself. They gathered writings about the nature of creativity through history, and formed novel hypotheses about it. Eventually they discovered something remarkable: A Unified Theory of Creativity that described how natural, biological, and human creativity are connected. They resolved a god-like object, the Ultimate Community, which described the universe as a grand adventure between creative events through all of space and time. Creativity had become omnipresent, a principle of existence itself. With humans, creativity had created co-creators, human creative experience was an extension of the Eros of the universe itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Unified Theory of Creativity had the effect of making followers of the Cult of Creativity even more devout and motivated to spread the message of creativity. The theory also led to the development of novel methods to help people cultivate their creativity both individually and socially. One member of the Cult of Creativity introduced an idea of a creative singularity, where the collective creativity of humanity would reach critical mass and become explosive, radically changing the way people thought and interacted with the world around them.

Now on a mission to change the entire world with the power of creativity, the cult worked harder than ever. They rapidly gained new members as word spread about how the message of creativity elevated people's lives and appreciation for life. They applied their creative experience to encourage cooperative problem-solving in politics and social disagreements, tackling the most difficult problems of their time. As the power of creativity grew, it became easier and easier to advance cooperation and empathy. The Cult of Creativity was on its way to becoming a global culture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Then one day a tipping point was reached, striking almost like a bolt of lightning. Nourished by creativity, the power of human goodness was now more powerful than the power of what is essentially socially transmitted bad habits, healing those bad habits on a globally massive scale. The most broken and unfortunate members of global society were lifted up, and found new lives with others. The problem of human conflict had been solved with the emergence of a massive web of mutually reinforcing non-zero-sum relationships that embraced the entire planet. War and exploitation was over.

With their global civilization now a Utopia, the Cult of Creativity had proven the limitless power of creativity once and for all. But they didn't stop there, they looked to the stars and learned to travel to them. They found a small planet inhabited by intelligent beings, who were troubled like they used to be. They wanted to help them, but not erase their own culture, and so they worked extremely gently, discreetly sharing a small idea or inspiration here and there, that would have snowball effects, letting natural cultural evolution do the work. Eventually the alien civilization experienced its own creative singularity, and were embraced by their alien friends as equals, with their own unique culture, history, and ideas.

existence is the struggle to exist; therefore, suffering is only what must be overcome, or that which is overcome, or what was overcome, in the duration of experience as a human being.
>suffering decreases
On the whole, yes, because you can cut away your earthly tether with a knife called wisdom. take up the knife and cut at yourself. cast away what made you suffer, leave behind these useless things. Then you may climb higher to heaven and leave suffering behind. But the truth is, suffering is human nature. Heaven will not save you. You will eat dust in enlightenment, because the soul can never change. You reduced suffering in the soul, but the soul is a boundless sea, suffering a boundless sky. They are mirrors of each other. You have only reduced your own perception of suffering.
>suffering increases
The wiser a man grows the more suffering comes into his life. Look at the suffering all around you, you who are grown so wise! Look at the reality that the life and ways you lived are in fact, base! You have approached the mystery, armed with a changing blade called wisdom. But who are you to grasp the divine with basal human knowledge? Suffering has made you come so far. To part with it, you would throw all your wisdom away. Suffering is the mountain you climb to grasp the mystery and it is the tower you stand in when you look down at lesser men. Your blade is wisdom, o knight, but hold the handle and feel a thorn cut your palm. That wound will never heal. The name of the handle is suffering. And that cut has never healed, so that you may be reminded of the nature of things. Your suffering has not increased. You have only been made acutely aware that suffering is the light that casts a shadow of wisdom; and as you climb, the light becomes ever brighter, ever more unbearable.

I'm not the other anon who spoke of the higher realms but in my school of Buddhism, what's defined as bliss is a transcendental phenomenon. Essentially, you shift away from your narrow, punctual awareness of your own body and tap into the universal one. As your view opens up, you experience the four types of bliss, which are accompanied by the four types of emptiness. The totality of existence is bliss-emptiness.
Separation from this totality (God, Brahman, and so on) is experienced as suffering.

I agree with you that the terminology is often hard to define, it has to be confirmed experientially in order to be understood.

>>33593651
Happiness and misery are like two sides of the same coin, or like a pendulum that bounces back and forth. If you tell me that the two sides are equal and only expressions of polarity, that's already good.
What we're really talking about when we say 'suffering' is focusing only on one side, expecting it to stay there.
What meditation eventually does is you stop the pendulum and let it sit there for a while. Then you realize the pendulum never changes despite going back and forth.
So when you experience feelings of joy or feelings of sadness, if you know it's all temporary and look at the big picture, that emotion self-liberates. Those emotions are like waves in the ocean of consciousness, which is like your true nature, unchanging.

posts.name: Omniquery
posts.com:
Once upon a time a group of artists, musicians, poets, scientists, philosophers, historians, theologians, engineers, and many others came together from a shared love of learning. They cross-pollinated each other's ideas and experiences with novel insights, helping each other to explore connections between fields they didn't consider before. The more they shared, the more interconnected they found themselves to be. They began to look at what they were doing, and found that their root commonality was creativity. And so they began to worship creativity itself, considering creativity as the most important thing in the world.

The Cult of Creativity spread the message of creativity by organizing public lectures and talks, workshops, star parties, funded libraries, and inspirational messages about the power of creativity. The cult grew and grew, and was welcomed by many as a learning movement.

The cult also investigated the nature of creativity itself. They gathered writings about the nature of creativity through history, and formed novel hypotheses about it. Eventually they discovered something remarkable: A Unified Theory of Creativity that described how natural, biological, and human creativity are connected. They resolved a god-like object, the Ultimate Community, which described the universe as a grand adventure between creative events through all of space and time. Creativity had become omnipresent, a principle of existence itself. With humans, creativity had created co-creators, human creative experience was an extension of the Eros of the universe itself.

posts.name: Omniquery
posts.com:
>>33600395
The Unified Theory of Creativity had the effect of making followers of the Cult of Creativity even more devout and motivated to spread the message of creativity. The theory also led to the development of novel methods to help people cultivate their creativity both individually and socially. One member of the Cult of Creativity introduced an idea of a creative singularity, where the collective creativity of humanity would reach critical mass and become explosive, radically changing the way people thought and interacted with the world around them.

Now on a mission to change the entire world with the power of creativity, the cult worked harder than ever. They rapidly gained new members as word spread about how the message of creativity elevated people's lives and appreciation for life. They applied their creative experience to encourage cooperative problem-solving in politics and social disagreements, tackling the most difficult problems of their time. As the power of creativity grew, it became easier and easier to advance cooperation and empathy. The Cult of Creativity was on its way to becoming a global culture.

posts.name: Omniquery
posts.com:
>>33600401
Then one day a tipping point was reached, striking almost like a bolt of lightning. Nourished by creativity, the power of human goodness was now more powerful than the power of what is essentially socially transmitted bad habits, healing those bad habits on a globally massive scale. The most broken and unfortunate members of global society were lifted up, and found new lives with others. The problem of human conflict had been solved with the emergence of a massive web of mutually reinforcing non-zero-sum relationships that embraced the entire planet. War and exploitation was over.

With their global civilization now a Utopia, the Cult of Creativity had proven the limitless power of creativity once and for all. But they didn't stop there, they looked to the stars and learned to travel to them. They found a small planet inhabited by intelligent beings, who were troubled like they used to be. They wanted to help them, but not erase their own culture, and so they worked extremely gently, discreetly sharing a small idea or inspiration here and there, that would have snowball effects, letting natural cultural evolution do the work. Eventually the alien civilization experienced its own creative singularity, and were embraced by their alien friends as equals, with their own unique culture, history, and ideas.

>>33610413
What OP is pointing out is logical. Yes, amino acids are everywhere in the universe, and RNA is nothing more than a chain of these amino acids which pair up with other acids to replicate itself, however the process of replication required the machinery of proteins to work effectively. We are kind of left with a chicken and egg paradox, how could RNA replicate itself without the necessary proteins to assemble and unbind RNA. We know that cells produce the proteins necessary for this process, however in a world without proteins producing more of themselves RNA cannot reproduce, and without RNA the proteins have no way of storing information so that they can reproduce. We are missing this big link in exactly how we went from RNA randomly forming and it actually achieving self replication, and the big mystery is proteins. Given that it might be exceedingly rare for both RNA to arise with the code to replicate itself and proteins, and the proteins to arise with the capacity to actually replicate this RNA, OP may be correct in his assertion

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

So, for the past few years I had been a gnome truther as a joke but recently I had a weird experience. My roommate had left for a week and when I was alone in the flat a gnome was visiting me. The creepy fucker would keep peeking at me from behind a corner and I would just ignore him cause I thought it was just my imagination fucking with me or something. 3 nights ago I woke up in the middle of the night and saw him right next to a book shelf in my room. The mother fucker was just staring me down and I made eye contact. After a minute he ran under my bed and seemed to have vanished by the time I jumped out of bed to investigate. But he had to be something physical because when he ran from my bookshelf under my bed he disrupted the bookshelf to the point that some of my books had fell over and one even fell from the shelf. I don't think the book that fell off the shelf really matters but in case it has importance of any sort it was a pocket version of the Quran.
The gnome itself was approximately 2 feet 4 inches tall and his red hat probably added another 4 inches and I know this because the bookcase he stood next to is 3 feet tall and his figure, hat included, was shorter than the bookshelf but almost as tall as the bookshelf. He had pale white skin of a pinkish complexion, small button looking nose, a white beard and blue eyes. He was wearing brown boots, pointy red Phrygian cap with a blue and white ribbon, denim-looking overalls and a long sleeve blue and white striped telnyashka-looking shirt.
Now I'm still a little suspicious that this was even a gnome because the height of it was a little taller than what I had imagined a gnome to be but I cannot just let this experience stay in my head. Has anyone else encountered a gnome? What did you do? What should I do?

I don't know how to cope with ego death.

I took two megadoses of shrooms and on both occassions, I experienced ego death. The first experience was very educational. The second was very humbling. But now I run into the problem in that most things in human life, and especially our society seem like complete illusions.

Nothing seems to have any real point any more. If life is just a short experience followed by death, why should I bother engaging in anything apart from hedonism? Why should I have goals and ambitions for fleeting material items, now that I feel they are all hollow? Following this, why bother engaging in any social conventions if they don't explicitly bring me pleasure in some fashion? Ego death was supposed to humble me, but now I feel bankrupt and cold. Detatched from this existence, peering through an impenetrable glass wall as I view, apparently objectively, what seems to be the lives of the mammals I once called fellow humans. The idea of "oneness" also is terrifying to me. That I may be the only conscious being, endlessly living in fable worlds created by my own consciousness to escape the impentrable question of my own existence, and being. In that I am solipsistic.

I cannot make sense of these things. I truly felt I was not ready to handle this, and I don't think any of us can really handle it. I don't know what do to.
