>>33596720
Kabbalah is a school of thought. An old-school of thought. Medieval really. Concerning God's process of creation, or "emanation".

It's only jewish in the sense that they continued to write about it long after everyone else stopped thinking about it.
Today, Kabbalah is a much bigger subject today than it would have been in it's prime. There's so much surrounding context that was "common sense" in medieval times, but today it's obscure.

So like, you have to teach medieval cosmology. Again, that wasn't uniquely Jewish either. And agricultural metaphors that aren't really agricultural anymore because technology and practices change.

Like they used to use thresher boards. Beat a armful of stalks against a board fitted with rocks, to separate kernels of grain or whatever. The device was called a vain or van.
So Jewish mysticism is kind of the same way. Only instead of a board with rocks. They had a board with names of god, and they were trying to obtain kernels of truth. This kind of divination was forbidden in the old testament. "Thou shall not use God's name in vain".
Like saying "If I'm lying, may God strike me dead." *not dead, so I must be telling the truth*. That's the principle of it. Today, I don't think anyone who says "Oh my God" is invoking some power of a deus ex machina.

>Can you explain more
the servant songs in the book of isaiah make reference to a 'suffering servant' that puts his faith in the lord and is thus rewarded and delivered from that suffering. the book was written during a time of great political tumult for the israelites because they were at war with the assyrians and the priestly caste was desperately searching for ways to placate their followers (a move away from animal sacrifice can be seen here, as this was placing an emphasis on material wealth being the path to salvation, something that clearly wasn't working).

i type all of this because the servant songs are the basis for the messianic eschatology that would go on to characterize the christian worldview. at the time, messiah specifically referred to a king or High Priest important to the Jewish people within the PRESENT tense, traditionally anointed with holy oil. this term was universally applied to Cyrus the Great, who decreed that the Jewish people could return from exile in Babylon some time prior. this is to say that messiah had no prophetic connotations, it could be applied to anyone that did a service to the Jewish peoples, it was only during Christ's lifetime that it took on the 'savior' meaning, as the aforementioned political discontent was reaching new heights with the fall of the second temple in roman judea; this makes it out that Christ was not in fact the culmination of centuries worth of Jewish prophecy and scholarly debate, but instead a fairly expected claimant to a religious position of power in the heat of a very fast-moving sectarian movement spurred on by material conditions.

Always be on the lookout for people trying to shoehorn modern astronomy into medieval cosmology.

Like in this image, >>33601912
Uranus, Neptune, and Pluto are not visible stars. They weren't even named until basically the 1800s. They don't belong on the tree, they don't have any symbolic significance.

The spheres can correspond to the 7 heavens. But after Saturn you have the Firmament and then God | Heaven | a realm of endless endless light.

Daath means knowledge. Like the gnostic Sophia, the Aeon of Wisdom. It's not there because it's fallen into Malkuth. The kingdom. The world. Material Existence.
In the jewish tradition this was the garden of eden until Adam and Eve ate of the fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
The 22 paths conveniently correspond to the 22 Hebrew letters, but also the 22 major arcana. The easy one to remember is the lowest path connecting to Malkuth. It's "The World".

The other thing to be mindful of is that the hermetic kabbalah tree has different paths. In the OP, you see Malkuth only has 1 path. But in the Hermetic tree it has 3.
In the Jewish sephirot, the path through all the spheres is a zig-zag. But on the Hermetic tree, there is no path connecting Binah to Chesed.
There's still 22 paths, but there are different correspondence. However "the world" tarot path is at least consistent between both versions.

The question you should be asking isn't "Why do Jews reject Jesus?", it's "Why is the concept of Jesus so foreign to Judaism?"

Christians say Jesus is the Messiah, Jews say they're waiting for the Messiah. So what's the big deal? The problem is that the Christian concept of the Messiah is completely different from the Jewish one. Groups like Jews for Jesus and Messianic Judaism try to paper over the difference but it just doesn't work.

If you want a history of early Christianity, go listen to lectures by Bart Ehrman. He's a real scholar, not a youtube schizo. The tl;dr is that the Jews of the 1st century expected a Messiah to kick the Romans out of the holy land and rebuild Jerusalem. The world would repent of their pagan beliefs, everyone would convert to monotheism, there would be world peace. Jesus, in his lifetime, accomplished absolutely none of this. Early Christians failed to find a significant audience with the Jews and began to preach to Romans. Over the years Christian sects popped up and each had their own twist on the story. Jesus went from a prophet to a demi-god to the literal son of god.

By the time you get to the 3rd century Judaism had moved on from expecting the messiah any time soon and Christianity had redefined the messiah from a prophet into god. It's why rejection of the law of Moses is baked into Christianity; they spent centuries removing as much Judaism as possible because their audience didn't give a shit about Judaism beyond historical curiosity. Constantine needed a tidy religion to unite the people and Romans were no strangers to going with the flow when it came to religion. The Jews, despite getting their asses handed to them and most of them straight up kicked out of the land, shifted their religion from being based around the temple to one based around the TaNaKh.

You're generally right, but not providing some context. Messiah (mashiach) has different connotations in Judaism than in Christianity. In judaism, a mashiach is someone anointed by God to lead the Jewish people and champion Israel. Cyrus wasn't believed to be the mashiach, he was a mashiach. He returned the people of Israel to Zion. The Christian messiah refers to him who is often referred to in the Jewish tradition as "melech mashiach," or the anointed king. Jewish prophecy (that Jesus does not meet the standards of) refers to a king of the Davidic line who will usher in the end of days, when we all enter a world to come where all recognize the divine and live in perfect harmony, essentially. The "Christ" in Jesus Christ comes from khristos, which is just Greek for anointed, so Joshua the anointed. This is just what I remember from my paltry education from reform Hebrew school, so I invite correction.

I had a mental breakthrough less than 2 months ago. I started reading Carl Jung's 'The Undiscovered Self' and just after the first 3 chapters something unlocked in my mind. It might've been more than just the book that did it, but my way of thinking had become different. I began questioning a lot of things in my life and came up with theories that I had thankfully written down. I also began noticing symmetries in life and at that same time a certain James Webb telescope photo was posted online that just pushed me further into it. The galaxies were somewhat lined up in symmetrical patterns! *photo attached*
As of now, my mind isn't where it was then. I've gone back to a somewhat normal thinking style while still attaining that knowledge. I had given up weed almost a month ago and as it was leaving my system I feel that sort of curious thinking style dissipate with it. Health wise its for the best, but perhaps I can return there with a sober mind. I just need to work towards that again.
In that short time though, I discovered important things about myself and realized which aspects belonged to my shadow self. With that particular knowledge I've gained much more self control (which was my main goal). But aside from that, I've developed theories about the power of perception, emotional energy, the importance of mental association, and personal truths. Most importantly out of all of this though, I've begun to reconnect myself with God.
[ANYWAY] with all that said, I've come to the conclusion that each one of us has a personal truth that isn't true for anyone else. Each and every one of our individual lives are unique no matter how basic they may seem, and with that uniqueness is an equally unique truth. What is true to you isn't exactly true for somebody else even though there are similarities. The only true answers we have are for ourselves, but we can ask one another important questions that can lead them to their truths.

So if you're dreaming of being big and strong, great, you will reach it one day, but first you need to break your dream down into smaller parts. Is there a gym nearby? Can you afford the gym? Break it down, come up with a plan, and try. That right there is 100% mind/will power. Still gotta do the work though, and thank fuck for that: if you didn't, the accomplishment would be meaningless, to you and others.

Taken from the link: 1/2

Back in the day, when I was in college, me and the oldest took off to a lake in the wilds of glacier country. I have extensive backcountry exposure, even did a stint as a big game guide in a remote backcountry camp. On this day we enjoyed the fishing and settled in for the night.

I pulled out my pan and stoked up a nice fire. It was clear and cool as the sun faded into the western slopes. We cooked up some fresh rainbows with garlic and butter and filled our stomachs. I leaned back against the cooler after pulling out a refreshing beverage. The boy was soon asleep by the fire as it had been a busy day. I sipped my beer and watched the moon light bouncing off the little waves in the lake. There was still a light glow on the western horizon where the sun had gone down and I could see the outline of the mountain peaks towering over the little lake. I slowly faded off to sleep with the sound of the lake waves gently lapping on the rocks.

I awoke with a start. The fire was out, the lantern was out too. The moon was gone and it was pitch black. Something was wrong. The hair on the back of my neck stood straight out. I was paralyzed. I could hear my heart thumping as I strained to hear something in the bush, all was quiet. I had a horrible uneasy feeling. I gathered myself together and started kicking around the fire, a small flame came alive and I quickly threw on some wood. In the firelight I could see that the boy had awoke and was shocked to see his wide open eyes staring at me. "What's wrong?" he asked. "Nothing, go climb in the tent." I lied. He crawled into the tent but even in the light of fire I couldn't shake my wariness. Something was out there in the bush, and I could feel it was watching me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33579750
2/2

I gathered up my light and flashed around camp. Nothing. Finally, I began to calm down and crawled in the tent with the boy. Then again, like clockwork, I awoke completely tense. This time I couldn't shake the feeling at all. I finally instructed the boy to wake up and go get in the truck. I packed up all of camp and drove around to the other side of the lake and slept with him in the truck. At dawn I got up and looked across the lake where we were camped earlier, and another uneasy feeling came over me. I decided it was time to go home. I don't know what was out there, or what was going on over there, but I know my instincts, and something was bad wrong with that place. Whatever it was, I will leave it to your imagination, it creeps me out to this day thinking about that night.

Not my story, and I'm sure I've shared it before, but it was a bit of a weird one as far as I'm concerned. Probably disappointing to anyone who reads it.

>Member of this forum back in the 2000s
>It's a music forum, but it has subforums for offtopic things like movies, sports, general chat, that kind of thing
>Another thing about it is that it was a local forum with everyone living within ~60 miles of each other so there was much, much less trickery because you didn't want a reputation for being a retard
>Sometime between 2006 and 2009
>User on there says he's just bought a webcam and it picked up something strange
>This was some years ago and it's not like the 4KUHD ones zoomers have now
>This was a piece of shit 2 frames per second kind that we had back then
>Anyway he had set his camera up to record just to test it out
>Middle of the day in one of the rooms (I think it was his bedroom)
>It didn't record like newer ones do, it was more like it took a pic every X amount of seconds or whatever
>Posts the pics up
>See him sitting at his computer
>Dad shouts of him and he goes to see what he wants
>See him leaving the room
>Camera still clicks away
>It's just his bedroom
>Then on two frames there's this really odd thing like a tattered translucent black sheet just hovering in the middle of the room
>Not on any other frames
>Just his bedroom again
>Then he comes back and sits back down at his computer
>Only finds it when he goes back through the pics and then posts them to the forum

One of the most convincing spook pics I've seen because, like I say, I knew the people on there irl and they would have no reason to try and fake spooky pics. Especially when he wasn't that type of person anyway and it wasn't that kind of forum.
Never bothered saving them because I was under the impression the forum would stay around forever. Instead it shut down a few years ago.

>>33605973
Hermetically-speaking, earth is *symbolically* feminine. The problem arises when adherents of symbolic systems confuse their signifiers with the things they signify. Symbolic systems are merely cultural constructs — some systems may seem more *accurate* or *successful* than others, but all symbolic systems carry with them various biases, inconsistencies and blind spots and those favored in a particular place or time may seem absurd to those operating in a different place and/or time.

"The finger pointing at the moon is not the moon" & yet more often than not you meet people who spend lives seeking understanding in the finger at the expense of any understanding of the moon.

Which is to say, the earth is neither feminine nor masculine (which are merely human categories that only pertain to a set of mammals that reproduce sexually, and to which humans belong — but are categorically nonsensical in any transcendental sense). Consider this:

Ms. Sexton went out looking for the gods.
She began looking in the sky
—expecting a large white angel with a blue crotch.

No one.

She looked next in all the learned books
and the print spat back at her.

No one

She made a pilgrimage to the great poet
and he belched in her face.

No one.

She prayed in all the churches of the world
and learned a great deal about culture.

No one.

She went to the Atlantic, the Pacific, for surely God…

No one.

She went to the Buddha, the Brahma, the Pyramids
and found immense postcards.

No one.

Then she journeyed back to her own house
and the gods of the world were shut in the lavatory.

At last!
she cried out,
and locked the door.

— Gods, Anne Sexton

Might sound like a copout answer, but the scariest shit I've seen on the Internet is honestly just its normalfaggotization after smartphones/socmed swept all before them and corporations and governments actually got their shit together and weren't getting BTFO'd by skiddies all the time. Took about all of two years for the dreams of a great future of decentralization, freedom, fun, and creativity to die so hard few even remember they were once held.

I've lived through multiple life-or-death medical emergencies, a lifetime of social isolation and an adult-lifetime of poverty, prolonged conflict with a man planning and attempting to murder me just for the lulz, more hellish hallucinogenic trips than I could count, and plenty more. Few things consistently bring me sadness and despair as much as remembering how full of hope and fun things online were before 2010, and then realizing nothing like that is ever going to happen again, and that most people around me weren't even there for it and don't realize they were actively complicit in its destruction.

I honestly think I have PTSD from this or something. It feels the town I grew up in was burned down and all its inhabitants slaughtered, and the pain of its loss has not diminished one micron since I first realized it was inevitable twelve years ago. The death of "old internet" taught me that all truly beautiful things in life are terribly fragile, and that a majority of humans are neurologically designed to trample on these things without noticing, call you an asshole for caring about them, then try to gaslight you into believing they were never there in the first place.

A long time ago I was incredibly interested in suicide and was voraciously reading all sorts of literature regarding the subject when I came across the story of a girl named Christina.
She had found some message board run by a genocidal cult that regularly educated people on how to kill themselves.
She had been instructed on such a method. They taught her how to impersonate an amateur gemologist that was in need of cyanide for her hobby and how to purchase it from certain places.
Then she went to a hotel room, ingested the cyanide and died moments later.
Her live journal blog was still up because her parents wanted it to be there. I eventually found it and read every message and sure enough the last one written by her could be mistaken for an Anon post on 4xhan for its desperate nature.
It was barely a sentence. I still remember it.
"something happen


NOW!"
And a week later she killed herself.
The blog has since been taken down and most messages after her last one were her parents commemorating her birthday. Something I found as a common trend when suicide victims had blogs.

The whole thing shook me quite a bit. Not only that there were people out there with a genuine interest in seeing people kill themselves but that it had worked on what appeared to be a very charming quirky young girl.
Last I heard they were still in operation despite heavy law enforcement involvement in Christina's case.

Same feeling here, though for me it lasted a bit beyond 2010, I'd say it really felt over by 2017, and absolutely dead beyond belief by 2019.

It's almost as if there's some dynamic about normalfaggots that they exist to somehow paper over consciousness itself, I used to have so many cool connections online even if they were fleeting, I'd get involved in arguments or debates or discussions, but now it's almost impossible to find someone who will even give you 5 minutes. I used to spend a lot of time on 'therapy' sites which were filled with fun people making connections and learning about one another and their struggles, sometimes flirting and going beyond and so on, but now those sites, despite having seemingly more people on them, are now filled with people who end conversations in seconds, most of them are are catfish or guys trying to start up a 'sex chat' fruitlessly.

I think the closest thing that touches on this in mainstream culture was 'Matrix Resurrections', where it talks about how the machines decided to concentrate a significant portion of the population with essentially NPC's, programs that act like humans but keep humans separately and unable to connect with other another. The movie is really about that - this struggle to find authenticity or connection where everything is reduced to talking points, lame corporate babble, or irony.

I was very alone before I found connection online, but then having experienced it, it feels even worse to be unable to find anything like that connection anymore, and to feel like everything is saturation with noise or disruption.

That outcome was inevitable though. The internet was developed by CERN and the military and there was always a lot of overlap between silicon valley, "counter"culture glowies, and weird behavioral modification stuff like cybernetics. We would never have gotten the internet if they didn't think it could be used to manipulate and spy on us.

Also even when the internet was more free, that freedom didn't tend towards any positive or spiritually healthy direction. I'm a mid 90s kid so I'm not old enough to have been around for "golden age" 4chan but I was around for enough of the afterglow to know that it was a degenerate cesspit. Gore threads, psyopping mentally disabled people like Chris Chan (and later on Terry), ultra degenerate porn, people laughing at actual murder, cultures like /r9k/ that fed on and reinforced negativity. 8ch was the same. Freer than the internet is now, funny, and it had a higher standard of discussion, but you still had people celebrating mass shootings and stuff.

I don't want to see internet anonymity, to the extent that it still exists, end because the alternative would be worse, but it's true that being able to interact with people without seeing them face to face or hearing their voice brings out people's most sociopathic impulses.

>>33609372
Man I've worked at a morgue for about 6 years. I'll tell you that when human remains are in a cooler and they aren't shrouded they start to burn from something called "wind swipe". The cooler fans blow moisture away from the tissues causing them to dehydrate and darken pretty significantly. The fans blowing directly on the bodies would surely cause this issue.

The fact that these bodies don't seem to have any wind swipe going on makes me think it's fake, but people can be really crafty when it comes to preserving human remains.

You can also stack more bodies vertically if they all lay horizontal. Easily 7 every 6 feet. This would be a waste of space.

>>33596323
Yes, undeniably. In fact, it's kind of a red herring to say 'without chemicals' insomuch as it suggests that with chemicals people can perceive 'beyond the veil' in the same way as those who are naturally gifted in this regard. Firstly, one is at the mercy of 'the chemicals' and secondly, 'chemicals' are not enhancing the mind so much as impeding certain mental functions that often get in the way of subtle perceptions. But any 'chemical' can only do a partial job. There's a reason why so many traditions emphasize stillness, meditation, a quieting or focusing of the mind, or entering into a state of unknowing (or confusion) in order to access the 'ethereal' realms. Chems are a hack, but an imperfect and partial hack at best.

Another problem is the metaphor of a veil — it's not as though the curtain is pulled back to reveal a sad man from the midwest rather than the great and powerful Oz, so to speak. Those who glimpse behind the veil and take what they perceive at face value are often more lost than those who have never accessed these subtler realities. There is as much illusion and unreality that occurs 'behind the veil' as there is occurring in the foreground.

Frankly this topic would require thousands of pages and many more thousands of hours of reflection to do it justice, and much of this work still exists in various legacy formats, but ultimately each person has to do the work for it to be meaningful in the bones, so to speak.

That /x/ treats such complex and subtle phenomena in such a crude and superficial way is frankly an embarrassment; but worse yet, /x/ doesn't know enough to be as embarrassed as it should be.

I don't write this merely as a put-down, but as a way to flag such discussions for the inexperienced, and to say that they should take anything and everything they read on this frighteningly agenda'd site with a skeptical eye and more than a grain of salt.

>>33610082
Even some of Suda 51's later games count.

Killer is Dead is psychological horror game pretending to be a typical beat-em-up. Yes there are "dating game" minigames in between levels to break the tension, but that's not a bad thing. Pic related: the first boss in the game. It's dark both literally and figuratively so keep the gamma turned up!

Shadows of the Damned is basically a roadhouse movie channeled through an angry drunk Mexican. It's a puzzle-combat hybrid with demons and occult themes everywhere.

Your mileage may vary, but I find No More Heros 3 to be kind of disturbing. Look at the alien designs as a start. And then there's the bleaker tone where lots of good guy team people get killed, go mad, or are assassinated. For something usually action and comedic heavy, it has a surprising darkness.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33604814
I take it you weren't there for Eternal September? Everything was OK, then suddenly Nornalfags. Normalfags everywhere. The only difference between now and then is that there are more walled gardens now than there used to be. The slow speeds didn't stop normalfags at all. And yes, they were just as brainless and insipid then as they are now.

That said, I remember back in the 90's we dreamed of things like we have now. Free anonymous forums with file capabilities. Remote access of an entire hard drive's worth of files in an instant. Massive archives of all the webpages and books in the world- free! Hell, just being able to listen to a song you like in decent quality without waiting 2+ hours for a download would have been great! We live in a literal cyberpunk world and nobody notices it.

It's not the net speed that is the problem. It's surveillance, lack of privacy and disregard for the user's wishes. We had all that crap going on before Eternal September, too, and it hasn't stopped. On the bright side, the faster speeds and higher proliferation of the internet has made it easy to warn people and help folks get mobilized. Between user tools and good groups like the EFF, we have tools to fight for basic rights that we didn't have back in the 90's. Tools we would have loved back then.

Ok, I will agree that the internet uses too much electricity. Bitcoin is the big culprit there. When things were peer to pere or peer to server it wasn't so bad. But when you add in peers that are servers like on a blockhain, power requirements get insane! Staking is bad. Mining is worse. I don't think they realized that "software eats the world" would apply here. And it shows.
